speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you for your call, Lorraine.  And now, before we break for a commercial, Roz has an important message.  Roz? _He looks over, but Roz isn't in her booth.  Frasier sits for a moment, then speaks up._

speaker: Frasier
text: What's that, Roz?  Can't come to the mike right now? Well, what she wanted to say was... _He gets up, leans over and tries to read the notice through the connecting window._

speaker: Frasier
text: Tomorrow, on Amber Edwards's "Book Chat," sociologist Lamont Myman discusses his book, "Violence in the Workplace: Why Co-Workers Kill."  Something which becomes more relevant With each passing moment.  We'll be right back after these messages. _CUT TO: the hallway. Roz is pounding on the candy machine and yelling.  Frasier comes out._

speaker: Roz
text: Cough it up, you piece of tin!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz!

speaker: Roz
text: What are you doing out here?

speaker: Frasier
text: One might ask the same question of you.  Isn't it customary to wait until the show comes to a complete stop before exiting?

speaker: Roz
text: I have a little urge. [_She pounds on the machine again._] Damn it!

speaker: Frasier
text: What is the matter with you?

speaker: Roz
text: [_rocking the machine_] I have GOT to have some CHOCOLATE! It's kind of a celebration.  At 11:07 this morning, I finished one of those magazine diets: Seven Days to a Healthier, Calmer You. _She shoves her hands in the drop part of the machine, Frasier comes up and grabs her._

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, Roz.  Come on, come on, Roz, come on.  Look, I'm doing this for your own good.

speaker: Roz
text: Wait!  Something came out. [_She reaches in and grabs it._] Oh, damn!  Chocolate covered raisins.

speaker: Roz
text: I'd like to meet the idiot that came up with these.  Take a grape, let it shrivel into a disgusting little wart and cover it with perfectly good chocolate. [_She rips the package open._] What the hell.  I'll just suck the chocolate off.

speaker: Frasier
text: Be sure to save what's left, maybe you can make some wine. _He goes back to his side, Niles comes into Roz's booth.  He stares at her for a few moments as she sucks the chocolate off and spits the raisins into a paper cup.  She finally notices him._

speaker: Niles
text: See all those years of finishing school really paid off.

speaker: Niles
text: Mon frere?

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm?

speaker: Niles
text: We're in luck! _He hops up on the console and a piercing tone erupts.  He desperately stabs at the buttons, until Frasier hits one on his console to shut it off.  Niles carefully eases up on the console._

speaker: Niles
text: I've just come back from my broker.  Meadow Wood Properties still has one share left in that mini-mall deal, I think we should go halfsies and buy it.  Give me five, bro.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm not giving you anything.  I told you I'm not interested.

speaker: Niles
text: You can't afford not to be interested.  It's a twelve percent return.  We've a chance to make a real killing here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, why is it so important to you?   You and Maris are already wallowing in money like a couple of yuppie hogs.

speaker: Niles
text: This has nothing to do Maris.  I'm making this investment entirely with my own money.

speaker: Frasier
text: And mine!

speaker: Niles
text: And yours!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, come on, Frasier, show some understanding.  Maris uses her money to emasculate the poor guy, and this is his pathetic attempt to stop feeling like a financial eunuch and regain some shred of his former manhood. [_giving Niles the once-over_] Such as it was.

speaker: Niles
text: [_un-offended, to Frasier_] Well?

speaker: Frasier
text: Twelve percent?

speaker: Niles
text: Net!  And, if you're unhappy at the end of the year, I'll buy you out and you can go back to that cozy two percent your bank is giving you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, okay.  I'm in.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, thank you Frasier!

speaker: Niles
text: And thank you, Roz.  That "financial eunuch" bit was inspired. Great stuff, great stuff.

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, well, look what I had to work with. _Niles makes a little "Well, right" toss of his head and leaves.  FADE OUT_ **SCENT OF A WOMAN** Fade in.  Martin is sitting at the table, clipping coupons.  Frasier is standing nearby. _

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, check this baby out: twenty-five cents off on a package of Butter Buds imitation utter.

speaker: Frasier
text: My, I can taste that scampi now. _He goes to throw some paper away.  Daphne comes in from her room wearing a red, oriental style dress._

speaker: Daphne
text: Well?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Daphne, very nice.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, thank YOU.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'd be more flattered if I didn't know how hard up you both are right now.  I'm going out with Derek again tonight.  But I'm having trouble choosing a fragrance.  I've got it pinned down to these two. [_she sprays one_] "Heather" - fresh and bouncy as a spring morning, or [_she sprays the other_] "Forbidden" -- your passport to erotic realms of pleasure.

speaker: Martin
text: How many times you been out with this guy?

speaker: Daphne
text: This is our third date.

speaker: Both
text: Forbidden.

speaker: Daphne
text: Why is it so important this is our third date?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_going to the couch and sitting down_] Well, Daphne, sexual mores being what they are in America, the third date is usually the place where two healthy adults decide whether or not to... take it to the next level.

speaker: Daphne
text: Excuse me?!  What kind of a randy custom is that?  First date, second date, whoops, let's all pitch our knickers?!

speaker: Daphne
text: The third date may mean that to you Americans, [_She opens the door to reveal Niles._] but it takes more than three dinners to get bangers and mash with Daphne Moon.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.  You look even lovelier than usual this evening.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you. _He comes in, then sniffs the air.  He turns around and gets closer to her to get a good whiff._

speaker: Niles
text: Is that "Forbidden"?

speaker: Frasier
text: In every sense of the word!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_heading for her room_] I think I'll just scrub me neck with an unscented soap.  If you ask me, you Americans have an unhealthy obsession with sex.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, I'm sorry we can't all be as chaste and restrained as the Royal Family. _Daphne turns and gives him a look, the goes to her room. Martin gets up and heads for his._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughing_] Good one, Dad!

speaker: Martin
text: I've been savin' it!

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I come bearing good news. I just spoke to my broker: Meadow Wood Properties has already leased eighty-five percent of the space in the proposed mini-mall.  Instead of twelve percent, they are projecting a fifteen percent return on our money!

speaker: Frasier
text: This is fantastic!  What say we go celebrate with a nice dinner at an exclusive boite?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, but the question remains, what boite?

speaker: Frasier
text: Charise?

speaker: Niles
text: Too noisy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Alsace?

speaker: Niles
text: Too bright.

speaker: Frasier
text: Papillion?

speaker: Niles
text: Too crowded.

speaker: Frasier
text: We've run out of boites.

speaker: Niles
text: A city this size and only three boites.

speaker: Frasier
text: How do we live?

speaker: Martin
text: [_coming from his room_] Hey, I'm goin' down to Duke's. What are you guys doin'?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we're trying to find some place to eat.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, when you get through, why don't you swing by and have a beer with me?

speaker: Frasier
text: At Duke's?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: Us?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: With you?

speaker: Martin
text: What am I speaking, Swahili?  Yeah!  You two.  At Duke's. With me.  A beer.  If you want.  Geez!

speaker: Niles
text: My God, do you believe that?

speaker: Frasier
text: No. No one in the family's ever been invited to Duke's.

speaker: Niles
text: Not even Mother, and there were times she could be quite the old rummy. _They thoughtfully rub their chins, again in unison.  Daphne comes from her room and gets her coat._

speaker: Frasier
text: I wonder why now, after thirty years, he's suddenly inviting us down there.

speaker: Daphne
text: Cheerio.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, Daphne.  Has Dad said anything to you about us and Duke's?  Has he been planning this?

speaker: Daphne
text: You mean... behind your backs?

speaker: Niles
text: Precisely.

speaker: Daphne
text: No!  What a couple of Wallys!  I mean, I have never met a family that worked so hard at being uncomfortable with each other.  Could it be that he just wants to lift a pint with his sons?

speaker: Niles
text: [_standing up_] No.  Duke's is where Dad hangs up with his cop buddies.  Where he goes to escape the stresses, strains and petty annoyances of everyday life.

speaker: Frasier
text: In other words, us.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I suppose you could sit around here analyzing why he invited you and end up frittering the night away.  Or, here's a thought: you could just go down there and find out for yourselves.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, for a lay person, she has a way of cuttin' right through the crap, doesn't she? **WHERE NOBODY KNOWS THEIR NAMES** _Scene 3 - Duke's Fade in.  There is a neon sign flashing "Duke's".  We pan across the bar to see a room full of working class men drinking, smoking and talking.  Martin is at the bar talking with friends.  Frasier and Niles enter and look around._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, my God, it's a room full of Dads.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, look, there he is, there he is!  Oh, look at him, holding court.  No wonder he likes it down here so much, they're all hanging on his every word.

speaker: Niles
text: Wow, that's the most fun I've ever seen him have without a remote control in his hands.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Frasier, Niles!  I'm glad you could make it.  Yeah, come on in, I want you to meet some of the guys I was on the force with.  Hey guys, these are my boys.  This is Frasier, he's on the radio.

speaker: Joe
text: [_yelling_] Hey, this is Marty's kid, the guy on the radio! _Everyone cheers and shakes his hand.  Niles looks a bit put out at being ignored._

speaker: Joe
text: Hey, Frasier.  Joe Herman.  Nice to meet you.  Hey, check this out.  "I'm listening."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_humoring him_] It's like hearing a recording of myself.

speaker: Niles
text: [_pulling on Martin's sleeve_] Dad?  Dad, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: What?  Oh, yeah, and this is my other son, Niles.  He's a psychiatrist, too. [_No response._] He married money! _Everyone yells "All right!" and "Way to go!"  Niles takes the attention happily._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Duke.  Duke, come on, I want you to meet my boys. Yeah, this is Frasier, and this is Niles.

speaker: Duke
text: Hey, how are ya?  Hey, how about a couple of Duke's Specials for you guys?

speaker: Niles
text: And what would those be?

speaker: Duke
text: Boilermaker.  A shot of whiskey, beer back.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, darn, we've been drinking those all night.  Maybe it's time we switched to sherry. [_off Martin and Frasier's looks_] Two boilermakers, please.

speaker: Duke
text: It's great finally meetin' you guys.  Martin's been tellin' us about you since you were kids.

speaker: Frasier
text: Aw, Dad.

speaker: Duke
text: I tell you Frasier, we all felt terrible when you heard your wife was screwin' around behind your back.  What was her name again? Everyone: Lilith!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, it was a slow night, all right?! [_He grabs his beer and goes out on the floor._] All right, all right everybody, settle down here, settle down.  I wanna make a toast.  For thirty years, Duke's has been my home away from home.  I look around here tonight and I see a lot of friends, and I wanna say I'm gonna miss you.  And I'm gonna miss this joint too. And may there be a special place in hell for those SOBs who are tearin' it down to build some damn mini-mall. Everyone: Yeah!

speaker: Martin
text: Those snivelling, rat-face bastards from Meadow Wood Properties! Everyone: Yeah!

speaker: Martin
text: To Duke's! Everyone: To Duke's!

speaker: Frasier
text: Two more! _FADE OUT  End of Act 1  Act 2  Scene 1 - Caf e Nervosa Fade in.  Niles and Frasier are sitting at the bookcase table. _

speaker: Niles
text: Did you talk to your lawyer?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, he's examined the contract.  Our checks have cleared. I even talked to the general partner, he says there's no way they're willing to even consider moving the site.  The deal's going through.

speaker: Niles
text: Maybe we could have Duke's declared a historical landmark, it's been there forty years.

speaker: Frasier
text: I doubt that, Niles.  They already tore down Seattle's first Pony Express office to build this place.

speaker: Niles
text: Damn!

speaker: Roz
text: Here you go, guys, one cappuccino, one latte, and hey, these are on me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh!

speaker: Niles
text: This guilt is driving me crazy.

speaker: Roz
text: It should, you make about ten times more than I do.

speaker: Niles
text: Duke's was his whole life.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Niles, there's nothing we can do about it, really. You know, look at it this way: we're actually doing Dad a service, stopping him from going out and drinking.  And the other policemen as well.  Maybe we're even performing a community service.  Men with guns will have one less place to go and liquor up.

speaker: Niles
text: There's always Roz's place.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, what do you say about me when I'm not around?

speaker: Niles
text: I think the only way I'm going to feel better is if I just bite the bullet and tell Dad.

speaker: Roz
text: The way I see it, your situation is like a woman who has one crazy night and cheats on her boyfriend.  And the only reason for this woman to confess is to make herself feel better. So, the best thing she can do is just keep her mouth shut. Unless, of course, her boyfriend walks in on her and the other guy because he decides to come home from Portland on the midnight flight instead of driving back like he said he would, so in that case, he's the liar and why should she feel bad?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Roz, for that purely theoretical example.   Fact is, I happen to agree with you.  Niles, if we tell him now, it will only hurt him.  We've got to keep this quiet.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, I just don't think it can be done.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course it can be done!

speaker: Niles
text: You mean to say, you can look Dad in the eye, day after day, knowing you have destroyed his sanctuary, and not tell him? You can live with that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you're forgetting: I married Lilith, I can live with anything. **SLEEPLESS IN SEATTLE (you knew we had to do it eventually)**  _Scene 2 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  It is night, Eddie is on Martin's chair.  Frasier comes in from his room.  He walks over to the piano and turns on the neon "Duke's" sign.  He looks at Eddie, who stares back._

speaker: Frasier
text: You buy into an investment GROUP, Eddie, you don't know! _Eddie runs off to Daphne's room,  Frasier sits at the table. Martin comes in from his room and turns on the lights._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hi, Dad.  What are you doing up?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I reached over in my sleep and Eddie wasn't there.

speaker: Frasier
text: You need a woman, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Tell me about it.  Oh, you turned the sign on.  That was nice of Duke to give to me.  You hold a glass of beer in front of it, it turns green. _Martin goes into the kitchen.  After a pause, Frasier follows him. Reset to - the kitchen.  Martin is looking through the refrigerator as Frasier comes in._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Niles and I are investors in the company that's tearing down Duke's.

speaker: Frasier
text: We didn't know!  When we found out, we tried to get out of it, but we couldn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, geez, yell at me Dad, will you please?  Just hit me or something, hit me with your cane.  Just don't stand there. _Martin swings his arm over and pours milk down the front of Frasier's robe.  Frasier wipes it up and Martin puts the milk away._

speaker: Martin
text: Let me see if I got this right: in the last year, you give my chair away, you lose my dog, and now you demolish my bar. What's next?  I'm gonna find out you're the one who shot me in the hip?

speaker: Frasier
text: I have an alibi for that one.

speaker: Martin
text: You have an alibi for everything.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, it's not like I did this on purpose, I'm part of a huge investment group.

speaker: Martin
text: You know, I don't get it.  You guys stood there and watched me and my friends get all weepy and you didn't say anything.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, what did you want us to say?  "Say fellas, here's something ironic..."

speaker: Martin
text: Well, why the hell didn't you at least tell me?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know.  I guess... I guess maybe it was because when you invited me down to Duke's, it felt like we were finally getting closer.  It was a momentous step.

speaker: Martin
text: It was a beer!

speaker: Frasier
text: Not to me!  It was validation.  Finally I was one of the guys you wanted to hang out with.  I, I didn't want to spoil that.

speaker: Martin
text: I woulda had you down there before, I just figured it was the kinda place you'd look down your nose at.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_considering_]  Well, you're probably right.  Anyway, I'm sorry.

speaker: Martin
text: Well maybe I spent too much time at Duke's anyway.

speaker: Frasier
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, you know.  When you kids were growing up, maybe if I'd spent less time at Duke's and more time with you, maybe I'd be sittin' across from a son who put so much stock in one beer.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I was actually having a pretty good time down there at Duke's.  Until I found out I was the one responsible for obliterating it from the face of the planet.

speaker: Martin
text: I liked havin' you there, too, son.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you mind, Dad?  It's driving me crazy, it looks like hell.

speaker: Martin
text: [_getting up_] Hey, you know what?  We got a couple hours before that wrecking ball comes.  How 'bout you and I go down there and have one more beer?

speaker: Frasier
text: To Duke's?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: You and me?  Us, together?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, not this again!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, yeah, all right, great!

speaker: Martin
text: [_returning with a six-pack_] Just you, me, and Charlie Ballantine.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll meet you right back here in a minute. _He turns to head for his bedroom, but the front door opens. It is Daphne, coming home._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, good evening, Daphne.  Or should I say, good morning?

speaker: Frasier
text: How was your... date with Derek?

speaker: Daphne
text: We had a wonderful time.  First we went to dinner, then to the symphony.  Then we took a lovely moonlight stroll through the park.  He's a perfect gentleman, is Derek. _She goes to hang up her coat and go to her room, but the hem of her skirt is tucked up in the waistband and there is a tear in one of her leggings.  Most suggestive of all, she's missed a button in the back of her shirt and her bare back is matted with grass clippings.  Frasier and Martin stare after her as she exits._

speaker: Frasier
text: Apparently, in England, it's the fourth date. _Martin nods.  FADE OUT  Scene 4 - Duke's Fade in.  The bar is now stripped out.  Frasier and Martin are sitting on crates, drinking beers and singing._

speaker: Both
text: ...and I'll be here, in sunshine or in shadow.  Oh, Danny boy, oh, Danny boy, I love you so... [_Martin signals Frasier to raise his pitch, they finish_]

speaker: Martin
text: That was good.  That reminds me of old Mickey Doogan. I remember one Fourth of July, we were on mounted patrol, leadin' a big parade down Broad Street.  It was a real scorcher that day, musta been a hundred degrees, and I'm sittin' on top of a thousand pounds of hot, sweaty horse. I musta been complainin' a bit, 'cause as we ride by Duke's, Mickey gets fed up and says "If you want a damn beer so bad, shut up and get one."  So I ride old Agides right through the front door, right up to the bar and order myself a beer. Duke plays it cool as a cucumber and says "And what'll your friend have?"  I say, "Nothin', he's drivin."

speaker: Martin
text: I've told ya that one before, haven't I?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah.

speaker: Martin
text: [_rising_] Oh, what a place.

speaker: Frasier
text: You want another beer, Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: Sure, why not?

speaker: Martin
text: Sun's up.  You look around this place, in the golden early morning light... it's still a dump.  I'm gonna miss it, though.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, I know what it is to have a neighborhood bar. I remember the last time I walked out of my old watering hole back in Boston.  A strangely emotional day.

speaker: Martin
text: It's the people, I guess.  Saying goodbye to a lot of people.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Dad, just because you're saying goodbye to this place, doesn't mean you can't see your buddies just as much as you always did.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, it does.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, you're right.

speaker: Martin
text: But that's life, huh?  You move on.  Only a fool tries to fight it.

speaker: Martin
text: What are you doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm here to stop the demolition.  What are you doing here?

speaker: Martin
text: We came to say goodbye.

speaker: Niles
text: You may not have to.  I've alerted my lawyers.  I intend to stand here and face down the bulldozers.  I'm prepared to take this thing to the highest court in the land.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you don't have to do that.  I've had a discussion with Dad, he forgives us.

speaker: Martin
text: Sure son, don't worry about it.  It's okay.

speaker: Niles
text: Is it really okay?  I think NOT!  Because today it's Duke's, but tomorrow, it's Moe's.  And the day after that, it's Ernie's Tap Room.  See, I'm not just here for you, Dad. I'm doin' this for every little guy out there who found some solace at the end of a hard day by bellying up at his neighborhood bar.  I'm here to show faceless corporate America they can't just come in here without so much as a "How de do" and shove the little guy aside.  Even when I'M that faceless corporate America!  I'm here to fight the good fight, to show those sniveling rat-faced heathens there's still some fury pounding in the heart of John Q. Public! _A wrecking ball smashes through the main window, Frasier and Martin run out._

speaker: Niles
text: On the other hand, who am I to stand in the way of progress?  _He races for the door.  End of Act 2_
